xxl.core.cursors.identities

Class TeeCursor<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      • xxl.core.cursors.identities.TeeCursor<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>

    public class TeeCursor<E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>
    A tee-cursor provides a method to duplicate a given iteration. That means the iteration given to a constructor of this class can be consumed in the standard way but all delivered elements will also be inserted in the specified storage area, that is given to this tee-cursor, too. Then the given storage area can be traversed calling the cursor method on a tee-cursor.

    If you understand this class as an operator in an operator tree, this operator has one input iterations, namley the given iteration in the constructor, and is able to deliver several output iterations. The tee-cursor itself is one of this output iterations. By calling the method cursor() one can get a further output iteration. So a lot of output iterations can be produced, if the storage area can be traversed more than one time, and for that reason the input iteration's elements are duplicated.

    The tee-cursor is closed when, at a certain time, itself and all cursors returned by cursor() are closed. This can be changed by setting the explicitClose parameter to true in the constructor TeeCursor(Iterator, TeeCursor.StorageArea, boolean). Then, only a call to closeAll() closes the input and the StorageArea.

    Note: All output iterators are cursors that do not support the remove and update operation. The duplication of the input iteration is fulfilled by lazy evaluation.

    Depending on the implementation of the inner interface StorageArea, a tee-cursor can be based on queues, lists or files. This class provides standard implementations for the these kinds of storage areas:

    • TeeCursor.ListStorageArea
    • TeeCursor.QueueStorageArea
    • TeeCursor.FileStorageArea

    See Also:
    Iterator, Cursor, SecureDecoratorCursor

      static class  TeeCursor.FileStorageArea<E>

      static class  TeeCursor.QueueStorageArea<E>
      A TeeCursor.StorageArea that stores elemenst in a queue.
      static interface  TeeCursor.StorageArea<E>
      This interface is used to store the objects delivered by the iteration specified in a tee-cursor's constructor and to return them, if the method cursor of the class implementing this interface is called.

      Counter determining how often next has been invoked on the underlying cursor inCursor.

      The storage area where the input iteration's elements are buffered.

        storageArea - the storage area that will be used to buffer the input iterator

      • TeeCursor

        public TeeCursor(Iterator<? extends E> iterator,
                 File file,
                 Converter<E> converter,
                 Buffer<?,?,E> buffer,
                 int blockSize)
        Creates a new tee-cursor and duplicates the input using the given file.
        Parameters:
        iterator - the iteration representing the input of this operator.
        file - an instance of the class File representing the storage area that will be used in the method cursor() to deliver a further output-iteration of this operator.
        converter - the converter used to serialize the input iterations elements.
        buffer - the buffer that is used for buffering the file.
        blockSize - the size of a block of buffered bytes.

    • Method Detail

      • open

        public void open()
        Opens the tee-cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

        Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

        Specified by:
        open in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        open in class AbstractCursor<E>

      • cursor

        public Cursor<E> cursor()
                 throws IllegalStateException
        Returns a new cursor delivering exactly the same elements as the decorated input iteration returned by a call to the next method, because these elements have been inserted in the user defined storage area. Only the order, the elements may be returned in, can be different, because calls to next and peek are delegated from the cursor to the underlying storage area that may realize a special strategy. The remove and update operation of the returned cursor throws an UnsupportedOperationException due to the fact that a deletion of an element contained in a duplicated output iteration is not well defined and would produce a ConcurrentModificationException, because all other iterations get inconsistent.

        Note, that this method checks if the underlying storage area realizes a Singleton-Design-Pattern, so only one instance of a cursor may be returned by this method. Every further call throws an IllegalStateException.

        Returns:
        a cursor contaning the elements of the input iteration
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the storage area can only be traversed for one time, i.e., the isSingleton method returns true, but it is traversed for a second time.

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the tee-cursor. Signals it to clean up resources. This does not always close the input cursor, which is closed by closeAll() or, if {#explicitClose} is false, when this and all cursors returned by cursor() have been closed. After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guarantied to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the tee cursor remains in the state closed.
        Specified by:
        close in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        close in class AbstractCursor<E>

      • closeAll

        public void closeAll()
        Closes this tee-cursor, the input cursor, the storagearea and all cursors returned by cursor().

      • hasNextObject

        protected boolean hasNextObject()
        Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
        Specified by:
        hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the iteration has more elements, false otherwise

      • nextObject
